The VHL allele is associated with the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene, which plays a critical role in regulating the HIF (hypoxia-inducible factor) pathway. When VHL is inactivated, the HIF pathway becomes constitutively active, leading to uncontrolled expression of genes involved in angiogenesis, cellular proliferation, and fibrosis. This results in the development of hemangioblastomas in the brain and spinal cord, as well as renal cell carcinoma. Additionally, the activation of HIF leads to increased expression of VEGFA, PDGFB, and TGFB, which promote tumor growth and angiogenesis. The ARNT partner enhances HIF activity, further driving the pathological processes. The VHL mutation contributes to hereditary hematosperma and clear cell renal cell carcinoma, a malignancy commonly associated with VHL syndrome. Therefore, the biological effect of the VHL allele is the development of clear cell renal cell carcinoma and other tumors associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.

\boxed{Clear cell renal cell carcinoma}

The CDKN2A allele is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes p16, which inhibits cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK4/6). Loss of CDKN2A function leads to unchecked cell cycle progression, particularly at the G1 phase, by allowing the activity of CDK4/6 in conjunction with cyclins (CCND1, CCND2, CCND3). This results in reduced phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma protein (RB1), leading to E2F transcription factors becoming active. Activated E2F promotes cell cycle progression and proliferation. The loss of CDKN2A is associated with increased RB1 inactivation, leading to uncontrolled cell division and contributes to cancer development. Specifically, CDKN2A loss is linked to **retinoblastoma**.

The CDKN2A allele is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes p16, which inhibits cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK4/6). This inhibition prevents phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma protein (RB1), allowing E2F transcription factors to activate genes involved in cell cycle progression. A loss-of-function mutation in CDKN2A leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation. CDKN2A is a critical gene in the tumor suppressor pathway involving TP53, MDM2, and RB1. Loss of CDKN2A function is associated with increased activation of the cell cycle and decreased apoptosis, promoting tumorigenesis. This mutation is commonly found in various cancers, most notably **melanoma**. The loss of CDKN2A contributes to the development and progression of melanoma by disrupting the cell cycle checkpoint and allowing unchecked cell division.

\boxed{Melanoma}
